# Chapter 1: The Fracture at 14:37

The orchids were the color of bruised dawn—phalaenopsis in milky lavender, petals so flawless they looked photoshopped. Caro adjusted the final stem in the crystal bowl, her reflection fractured by the water’s surface. At exactly 14:36, Gangnam’s afternoon light slanted through the penthouse’s floor-to-ceiling windows, warming the marble beneath her bare feet. She hummed the Korean lullaby Min used to request when thunderstorms rattled the hanok’s old windows.

*Jajangga, again, eomma. One more time.*

She set the silver watering can on the kitchen island, the metal ringing like a bell. Her phone sat beside it, face-down, on Do Not Disturb. She never took calls between two and three—the hour belonged to her plants, to the silence she’d paid for with fourteen years of eighteen-hour days and a divorce decree stamped in three languages.

The elevator chimed softly, but she didn’t turn. The housekeeper knew not to interrupt the orchid hour.

Then her phone buzzed. Not a call—an encrypted video file, sender unknown. Caro’s thumbnail hovered. She hadn’t opened an unmarked attachment since Damascus, since the day the café exploded and she’d crawled out with someone else’s blood in her mouth.

But the timestamp on the file was 14:37:00. Exactly.

She pressed play.

The screen filled with darkness, then a sliver of light—a freight container’s door cracked open. Two figures knelt inside, bound at wrists and ankles. The first had Luna’s profile, the same stubborn tilt of chin she’d inherited from their mother. The second was smaller, thinner. Min. His Spider-Man T-shirt was twisted, riding up to expose a ribcage that fluttered like a trapped moth. Both were blindfolded. Both had straws taped to their mouths, the plastic quivering with each breath.

A distorted voice, genderless, scraped out the first line of their childhood lullaby. French first, then Korean, the languages braided like rope.

“Dors, mon trésor, 자장가를 불러.”

The video froze. A single line of text replaced it: *Return to the river. Dig where the truth bleeds.*

The watering can slipped. It hit the marble and rolled, clanging, water spreading like mercury. Caro’s knees buckled. She caught herself on the island’s edge, orchid petals scattering—bruised dawn turned to bruised everything.

“Min,” she whispered, the name cracking in her throat.

She dialed Luna. Straight to voicemail. She tried Min’s school—busy signal. Her hands shook so violently the phone slipped, skittering across the floor. She crawled after it, silk blouse soaking up water and crushed petals.

The penthouse’s intercom shrieked. Mrs. Park the housekeeper, voice tinny with panic. “Ma’am—there are men. In masks. They say—”

A click. Silence.

Caro’s reflection stared back from the floor’s mirrored surface: hair disheveled, mascara bleeding, orchid petals stuck to her cheek like shrapnel. The woman who’d once negotiated hostage releases with a calm voice and a spreadsheet was gone.

She pressed her forehead to the cold marble.

Four thousand miles away, Isa was crawling from a burning helicopter. They didn’t know that yet. They only knew the distance between them had never been kilometers or years. It was the secret they’d buried at the river, the one that grew teeth in the dark.

Caro dragged herself upright. Her reflection wavered, then hardened.

She reached for her keys.

The elevator doors opened onto the hallway’s sterile light. She stepped inside, orchid petals stuck to her shoes like accusations.

*Return to the river.*

The doors closed.

Wind claws at the open bay door, sucking the heat from every exposed inch of skin. Isa braces a boot against a red web net and leans into the slipstream, gloved fingers riding the pulse at the teenager’s ankle. It flutters once—twice—then steadies.

“Pressure’s dropping, Doc,” Jodie shouts over the rotor roar, one hand squeezing the blood-pressure bulb while the other pins the chart to her thigh.

“Give me sixty of ketamine, push,” Isa answers without looking up. Her voice is the same note she’s used for every casualty in every war zone for the last seven years: low, flat, impossible to disobey.

The pregnant girl—fifteen, maybe sixteen—lies strapped to a NATO litter, knees splayed, a crimson pad blooming beneath her. Sweat beads on her upper lip despite the January cold that turns every breath into frost. Her eyes roll white beneath half-closed lids, the lashes sticky with dust and tears.

Isa slides an ultrasound probe across the girl’s bare belly. The screen is a snowstorm of static, but she catches the flicker of a fetal heart at one-forty. Good. Still fighting.

“Contractions every four minutes,” Erik calls from the head of the litter. He’s Norwegian, cheeks wind-burned, headset askew. “Bleeding’s arterial—look at that spurt.”

“Clamp it or pack it. Jodie, another liter of O-neg wide open. Erik, prep the rapid infuser.”

Her own pulse feels distant, a metronome keeping time with the rotor thud. She’s beyond tired; she’s hollowed out and sanded smooth, the way driftwood gets after too many tides. But the body on the stretcher needs the version of her that never sleeps, so she stays in that narrow band of focus where nothing exists except vitals and verbs.

The Black Forest scrolls beneath them like black-green carpet, fir tops whipping past in stroboscopic flashes of moonlit silver. A patch of snow on a ridgeline glints like broken glass. Somewhere down there are villages and ski lifts and people who have never smelled cordite or birthing blood.

The girl whimpers. Isa bends close enough to taste the copper on the air. “Hey, small warrior. Stay with me.” Arabic, soft, almost a lullaby. “Dors, mon trésor.” The phrase slips out before she can stop it—then she clamps down, switches back to English. “You’re almost safe.”

“Doc, tail rotor’s running hot,” the pilot crackles through the headset. “Ten minutes to Ramstein.”

“Copy. Ten minutes,” Isa replies, but her mind is already triaging those six hundred seconds: pack the uterus, splint the pelvis, keep the airway open, keep the baby on the monitor. She’s done more in less.

A vibration she can’t name ripples through the deck plates, followed by a high metallic whine. Erik’s head jerks toward the rear. “Was that—”

The helicopter bucks, tail sliding left. The litter skids sideways; the IV line snaps taut. Alarms shriek as the g-forces slam Isa against the bulkhead. For a heartbeat, everything tilts: the girl’s pale face, the forest spinning below like a roulette wheel, Jodie’s mouth open in a silent shout.

Isa’s last coherent thought before the world fragments is absurdly clinical—Note to self: check shoulder for dislocation after impact—then the night rushes in, rotors howling, metal screaming, and the smell of aviation fuel floods the cabin like a promise already broken.

## Scene 2: The Black Forest Descent

The missile came from nowhere.

A streak of white fire that kissed the tail rotor like a lover’s betrayal. The impact felt soft at first—just a shudder through the airframe, a whisper of something wrong. Then the helicopter twisted, metal screaming as the world flipped sideways.

Isa’s headset tore off in the spin. The pregnant girl—Amira, sixteen years old and bleeding through her abaya—floated against her restraints, mouth open in a silent scream. The pilot’s hands were frantic on the cyclic stick, trying to coax life from dying hydraulics. Outside the windshield, pine trees spun in a dizzy carousel of green and brown.

“Mayday mayday mayday—” The copilot’s voice cut to static as the radio antenna sheared away.

The Black Forest rushed up to meet them. Isa had time to think: *This is where fairy tales come to die.* Then impact—hard, harder than she’d imagined death would feel. Metal folding like paper. Fuel igniting in a whoosh of heat that peeled paint from the fuselage.

She came to hanging upside down in her harness.

Blood ran into her eyes—warm, metallic. The world tilted at impossible angles through the cracked windshield. Amira was unconscious but breathing, each exhale fogging a small circle on the cracked plexiglass. Beyond the glass, smoke curled around tree trunks like incense.

The pilot groaned somewhere behind her. “Get out... fuel line...”

Isa’s left shoulder was wrong—dislocated, maybe worse. She bit down on the scream as she released her harness, dropping to the ceiling with bone-jarring force. The helicopter groaned around her, settling deeper into the pine carpet that had broken their fall.

“Amira.” She crawled across buckled metal, each movement sending fire through her collarbone. “Amira, wake up.”

The girl’s eyelids fluttered. “Cold,” she whispered in Arabic. “So cold.”

Smoke thickened, black and chemical. Through the broken windshield, Isa could see flames licking up the side of the wreckage, orange tongues tasting the fuel that pooled beneath them. The smell of burning aviation fuel mixed with something worse—cooked flesh, maybe. Maybe her own.

She got Amira’s harness unbuckled, cradled the girl’s head as she lowered her to what had become their floor. The pregnancy was high-risk—pre-eclampsia, the doctors at the field hospital had said. Now she was bleeding again, dark stains spreading across pale fabric.

“My baby,” Amira gasped. “Please—”

“I’ve got you.” Isa’s voice sounded foreign, like someone else speaking through her mouth. “We’re getting out.”

The emergency exit was jammed, warped metal refusing to budge. Isa kicked at it with her good leg, felt the impact travel up through her teeth. On the third kick, it gave way with a shriek of tortured aluminum.

Fresh air rushed in—cold, pine-scented, laced with diesel smoke. Behind them, something popped. The fire found the fuel tank.

Isa grabbed Amira under the arms and pulled. The girl weighed nothing—fever and blood loss had hollowed her out. They tumbled through the exit just as the helicopter coughed its first explosion, heat washing over them like a tide.

They rolled down a slope of pine needles and wet earth. The second explosion came when they were twenty feet away, close enough to feel the concussion in their bones but far enough that the shrapnel whistled overhead instead of through them.

Isa came to rest against a fallen log, lungs burning with smoke and altitude. Amira lay beside her, eyes closed, one hand resting protectively on her swollen belly. Beyond the burning wreckage, the Black Forest stretched in all directions—dark, ancient, indifferent.

Her phone buzzed.

The sound was wrong here, too modern for a place that had swallowed armies. She fumbled it from her pocket with shaking fingers, the screen cracked but still glowing. The caller ID showed nothing—just a string of zeros that hurt to look at.

She almost didn’t answer. Almost threw the phone into the flames that were now consuming what remained of the helicopter. But something in the rhythm of the buzz felt familiar, like a heartbeat she’d forgotten she had.

“Hello?”

The video began automatically. No buffering, no warning. Just Luna’s face filling the screen—her sister’s daughter, twelve years old and gap-toothed, now bound and blindfolded. A plastic straw protruded from her mouth like a feeding tube. Behind her, another child—Min, Caro’s son—curled into himself, small and terrified.

The voice that followed was not human. It had been processed through so many filters that only cadence remained, the rise and fall of syllables that belonged in their childhood bedroom in Busan.

“Dors, mon trésor, 자장가를 불러.”

*Sleep, my treasure, sing the lullaby.*

Isa’s phone slipped from numb fingers. The video kept playing, now showing the inside of what looked like a shipping container. Metal walls. LED strips casting harsh shadows. The children’s breathing sounded like waves against a shore.

Then: “Return to the river where you buried the truth. You have forty-eight hours.”

The screen went black. In the distance, sirens wailed—German emergency services responding to the smoke column that now rose above the tree line. Somewhere in the wreckage, Amira stirred and moaned.

Isa stared at the dying fire and understood two things with crystalline clarity:

The distance she’d spent seventeen years cultivating hadn’t just been geographic. It had been a lie she told herself, a story about safety and separation and the price of running from your own history.

And now the river was calling them home.

She stood, cradling her useless arm against her chest, and began walking toward the sound of approaching sirens. Each step hurt in ways that had nothing to do with dislocated joints or smoke-scorched lungs.

Behind her, the Black Forest burned.

The orchids arrived at dawn—white Phalaenopsis flown in from Jeju, stems wrapped in damp cotton and Korean newsprint. Caro lifts one from the crate with surgical care, the roots still dewy, breathing like gills. She positions it on the mirrored console beside the living-room window, where the Han River glints thirty-three floors below and the morning sun refracts through triple-pane glass. Every angle is measured: one inch left to catch the light, a quarter-turn so the lowest blossom faces the sofa. Her reflection—black silk blouse, pearl studs, the flawless side-part she’s worn since university—multiplies into infinity inside the mirror.

Across the room, Min stomps out choreography on a pale-wood floor that never saw a scuff until he learned to moonwalk. The tablet’s speakers thump a bass line Caro refuses to recognize; the boy’s T-shirt swings like a flag. He is all elbows and velocity, nine years of unchecked momentum.

“Min-ah.” Caro slides the orchid forward, aligning its spine with the brass seam in the mirror’s frame. “Line two closes at rush hour. You’ll ride with Mrs. Choi today.”

Min spins, sneakers squeaking. “Eomma, I’m not a baby.” He drags the last vowel into a groan, then drops into a squat, arms crossing over his chest in perfect sync with the dancer onscreen. The motion kicks up a faint smell of grapefruit from the diffuser hidden beneath the sofa.

Caro clips a dried aerial root with her shears. Snip. “The subway is a crush of strangers and a playground for perverts.” She keeps her tone level, conversational, the same register she used last week with the board of directors. “Mrs. Choi drives a Mercedes.”

Min’s bangs flop over his eyes as he pops up, hair still holding yesterday’s salon glaze. “All the kids take the train. Jisung goes alone. Jisung is eight.”

“Jisung’s mother does not have my enemies.”

The boy pauses the video. Silence blooms, heavy as the humidity trapped inside the orchid crates. Min looks at her—really looks—for the first time all morning. His irises are almost black, like river stones slicked by rain. “Do you have enemies, Eomma?”

Caro places the shears beside the orchid, aligning their handles parallel to the console’s edge. “Everyone with something worth taking has enemies.” She folds the damp newspaper into a perfect square. “Finish your stretches. We leave in fifteen.”

Min scowls but obeys, rolling his shoulders, counting under his breath in English—one and two and three—accent flawless from Saturday tutors. Caro watches the narrow blades of his shoulder blades beneath the cotton. So small, she thinks, yet already practicing how to vanish into crowds. The thought bruises her somewhere private.

The penthouse smells of orchid sap and imported citrus. Floor-to-ceiling glass turns Seoul into a silent diorama: toy cars on the Teheran-ro, ant-size salarymen scurrying toward glass towers that reflect the sky like polished knives. Here, thirty-three floors up, Caro has engineered a pocket of stillness—white orchids, white sofa, white noise. She checks her watch: 7:12 a.m. Nine hours and twenty-five minutes until everything fractures.

Min grabs his backpack—limited-edition, black with reflective chevrons—and jams the tablet inside. The zipper snags on the headphone cord; he yanks once, twice. “Eomma, can we stop at the bakery? I want the croissant with the chocolate inside.”

“We have croissants in the freezer.”

“They’re not the same.”

Caro lifts the tray of orchids. Porcelain clinks against porcelain as she carries them toward the kitchen island, each pot balanced on a linen napkin to prevent water rings. She hears herself sigh, a sound like silk tearing. “One chocolate croissant. Then straight to the subway entrance. Mrs. Choi will be waiting.”

Min beams, victory in eight-year-old terms. He skips ahead to the elevator, sneakers flashing like semaphore. Caro follows, heels silent on marble. In the reflective brass doors she sees them side by side: her posture a metronome, his limbs already jittering to the beat inside his head. The distance between their shoulders is exactly three orchid pots wide.

The elevator descends. Thirty-three. Thirty-two. Thirty-one.

Min hums the chorus of whatever song has colonized his brain. Caro closes her eyes. For a moment she smells pine needles and river mud, hears a lullaby in two languages braided together like rope. She opens her eyes. The doors ding open onto marble and morning light.

Outside, the city waits—dense, humming, anonymous. Caro tightens her grip on the tray. Porcelain trembles but does not crack.

The Black Forest tasted of pine sap and jet fuel. Isa hung upside-down in her seat harness, blood roaring in her ears louder than the dying turbine whine. A shard of rotor blade had punched through the cockpit glass; it quivered inches from her cheek, catching the strobing orange of the fire that licked along the fuel slick. Her left shoulder throbbed—dislocated on impact—and every heartbeat felt like a hammer against bone. The concussion fuzzed everything at the edges, turning the smoke into watercolor smears.

She clawed for the buckle with her good arm, the nylon strap slick with her own blood. Metal groaned overhead; the fuselage had come to rest at a forty-five-degree angle, tail buried in a thicket of spruce. Through the cracked windshield she could see the pregnant teen, unconscious but breathing, still strapped to the stretcher that had somehow stayed locked to the floor. Outside, pine needles hissed as they caught fire.

Her phone buzzed in the breast pocket of her flight suit. It should have been impossible—no signal this deep in the hills—but the screen lit anyway: an encrypted video, sender unknown. Time stamp 14:37. She thumbed it open with a shaking thumb.

The image was grainy green, night-vision inside a freight container. Luna sat cross-legged, wrists zip-tied, a strip of duct tape over her eyes. Beside her, a smaller figure—Min, Caro’s boy—breathed through a plastic straw jammed into a water bottle. A gloved hand adjusted the angle, and a distorted voice began to sing, the syllables mangled by auto-tune and static: “Dors, mon trésor, 자장가를 불러.”

Isa’s heart stopped mid-beat. The lullaby their mother had sung in two languages, the one no one else alive knew. The voice finished the line and switched to a metallic rasp: “Come back to the river where you buried the truth. Forty-eight hours. Alone.”

The video ended. The phone blanked to black, reflecting her own soot-streaked face. Somewhere outside the wreck, a fuel tank popped like a gunshot. Isa fumbled for the buckle again, shoulder screaming, every motion sending shards of light across her vision. She had to get out. She had to run.

—

Four thousand miles east, Seoul pressed noon sunlight into the floor-to-ceiling windows of Caro’s penthouse like polished brass. The apartment smelled of cedar shavings and orchids—three dozen rare white Phalaenopsis she had arranged on mirrored trays for a client tour. Each pot was balanced on slim steel stands, the petals so perfect they looked carved from porcelain.

Her phone chimed. 14:37. The same encrypted video. She watched Luna and Min in the green glow, the straw trembling with each shallow breath. The lullaby clawed its way up her throat—she hadn’t heard it in twenty years.

The orchid she was holding slipped. Ceramic cracked against marble, potting mix blooming across the floor like dark snow. One by one the rest followed, domino-slow: stems snapping, roots exposed, perfume thick as loss.

From the hallway came the elevator chime. Footsteps—more than one set—soft-soled shoes on lacquered oak. Caro turned, still clutching the ruined orchid, and saw the men in surgical masks framed against the light. Their eyes were flat, identical behind the white cloth.

The tallest held up his phone, the same frozen frame of Luna and Min onscreen. “Time’s already moving,” he said in Korean. “The river remembers.”

Caro’s knees buckled. Petals crunched beneath her heels as she sank to the floor, the lullaby echoing in her head louder than the breaking world around her.

The Line 2 train bursts from the tunnel into daylight above the Han River, windows flashing silver. Min grips the overhead rail, sneakers dangling inches above briefcases and designer boots. The smell of kimchi jjigae from someone’s lunchbox mixes with perfume and sweat. A phone rings with the same BTS ringtone as yesterday, and Min mouths the lyrics, counting stations until Gangnam—three more stops, then eomma’s orchids.

A man in a navy suit staggers against him. The apology dies on Min’s lips when he sees the surgical mask, white against stubble, and eyes that look past him like he’s already gone. Another mask appears behind. White cotton, elastic straps, no words. Between heartbeats they close in.

Min’s knuckles whiten on the rail. “Ajussi—”

The train lurches. Doors hiss. The first man’s hand clamps over Min’s mouth, tasting of latex and iron. The second slides an arm under his ribs, lifting. Min kicks; his sneaker strikes a metal pole with a hollow gong that nobody hears over the rush-hour roar. The masks move with choreographed calm, parting the crowd the way Moses split the sea. Passengers look down at phones, up at ads—anywhere but at the boy whose mouth is working soundlessly behind sterile fabric.

The doors start to close. Min’s fingers scrabble, catch the rubber edge. One fingernail peels back, hot and wet. A woman in a green hanbok finally glances up. Their eyes lock. Help me, Min screams without sound. Her gaze slides away.

They step off at Seolleung, masks bobbing like mushrooms. Min’s last glimpse of the train is his own reflection in the window, mouth stretched wide beneath the stranger’s palm, while inside the car a child keeps humming the BTS chorus he’ll never finish.

*

Three hundred feet above the Black Forest, the Eurocopter’s rotors beat the winter air into cold cream. Inside the cabin, Isa presses two fingers to the pregnant girl’s carotid—thready but there. Sweat mats the girl’s dark hair to the olive-drab stretcher; her belly rises like a hill under the thermal blanket. The medic beside her adjusts the IV drip with gloved hands. Out the window, fir trees scroll past in dark ranks.

“Five minutes to Ramstein,” Klaus calls through the headset, voice tinny over the turbines. The pilot’s blond stubble catches the console’s green glow. “Weather’s holding.”

Isa nods, though every muscle is braced for turbulence. She’s flown this route four times this month—Mosul to Ramstein, shrapnel to incubators. Routine, they call it, as if any flight carrying a fifteen-year-old mother and her unborn child can be routine.

The missile hits without sound. Just a white streak, a cough of smoke from the treeline, and then the world tilts.

The tail rotor disintegrates in a spray of carbon fiber and sparks. The helicopter whips sideways, centrifugal force flinging the medic into the ceiling. The IV bag bursts, saline glittering like glass in the sudden sunlight as the fuselage rolls. Isa’s seatbelt bites her collarbone; something pops hot and wrong in her shoulder.

Klaus’s hands blur over the cyclic, feet working pedals that no longer answer. The forest rushes up—a mosaic of pine and snow. The girl screams, high and thin, joining the mechanical shriek of dying engines.

“Brace!” Klaus shouts, but the word is already behind them.

Metal screams. Trees explode into splinters. The world folds in on itself, glass and blood and the smell of aviation fuel. Isa’s cheek smashes against the window; through spiderweb cracks she sees a red deer bounding away, untouched, while fire blooms in the rearview mirror of her retina.

*

14:36:57. In Seoul, the surgical masks hustle Min down a stairwell that smells of urine and wet concrete. His reflection stutters across broken tiles—small, dark-haired, drowning in adult arms.

14:36:58. In Germany, the helicopter’s belly skids across a clearing, rotors chewing earth until one snaps and cartwheels into the underbrush like a guillotine.

14:37:00. Both phones buzz with the same silent alert. A notification neither sister has the hands to check.

The deer vanishes between the trees. The subway doors seal shut. Somewhere in the static between two countries, a lullaby begins to play.

Rotor blades still cough sparks into the pine needles when Isa’s phone vibrates in the blood-warm pocket of her flight suit. She is on her knees, shoulder out of socket, helmet cracked like an eggshell. Smoke coils between the trunks, bitter with aviation fuel and scorched aluminum. Somewhere behind her, the co-pilot is screaming, but the sound is underwater, distant. Her left ear rings; her right ear hears only the soft electronic chime of an incoming Signal message.

The screen lights up with the same blue-white glow that once guided their childhood flashlight tag through the bamboo groves of Yongin. A thumbnail: a freight container, interior lit by a single LED strip. She taps it, hands shaking.

The video opens to Luna on the left, Min on the right. Both blindfolded in gray duct tape. Both wrists zip-tied to a metal pipe running overhead. A clear drinking straw has been taped into each of their mouths like obscene snorkels. Their chests rise and fall in shallow, panicked beats, fogging the straws with condensation.

A voice, genderless, flattened through a cheap filter, recites the sentence that once lulled them to sleep.
“Dors, mon trésor, 자장가를 불러.”
French first, Korean second. The cadence is exact, down to the half-second pause their mother always took between languages.

Then the voice hardens: “Return to the river where you buried the truth. You have until the moon turns its face.”

The clip ends. The forest wind rushes back in, carrying the smell of pine sap and burning rubber.

Isa doesn’t scream. She simply stops breathing for five full seconds, eyes fixed on the black playback triangle, until the screen dims and reflects her own soot-streaked face. She feels the dislocated shoulder throb in its socket, but the pain is a postcard from another country. Her mind is already moving—measuring distances, calculating borders, hearing the echo of a summer night twelve years ago when three sisters swore an oath beneath dragonfly wings and neon water.

She pockets the phone, staggers to her feet, and starts limping downhill toward the nearest logging road. Every step drags a memory behind it like a parachute.

Gangnam-gu, Seoul
Caro sets the last dendrobium into a crystal cylinder when the phone on the marble counter illuminates. The penthouse is all glass and winter light; the Han River glitters twenty-seven floors below like a cracked mirror. A string quartet rehearses softly on the built-in speakers—Debussy, because orchids like impressionism, her housekeeper once joked.

She sees the same thumbnail, same glow. Her manicured thumb hesitates over it, the oval nail catching a prism of reflected sun. Then she taps.

The video plays. Min’s small face is turned toward the lens, freckles stark against the gray tape. His straw twitches with every terrified gasp. Luna is beside him, older, paler, but Caro recognizes the birthmark under the blindfold’s edge—the faint crescent that always reminded her of a rice grain.

The lullaby line curls out of the phone’s speaker like a phantom ribbon.
“Dors, mon trésor, 자장가를 불러.”

Caro’s knees unlock. The orchid tray tilts, slides, crashes in a porcelain avalanche that sends water cascading across the heated marble. A single purple blossom lands upside down, stamens trembling like antennae.

“Return to the river where you buried the truth.”

The voice is a scalpel now, peeling back years of careful lacquer. Caro sees the river—not the Han gliding below, but the narrow, algae-threaded stream behind their grandmother’s house. She hears the shovel bite wet earth, the hush of three voices making a secret permanent.

The screen goes black. The Debussy continues, oblivious.

Caro’s hand hovers above the shattered orchids. A bead of blood pearls where a ceramic shard has sliced her index finger. She watches it fall—red on white, like the flag of a country that no longer exists.

Without wiping her hand, she crosses to the floor-to-ceiling window. In the mirrored glass, her reflection is cut in half by the city skyline. She lifts the phone again, types a single word to Isa—coordinates only, no greeting—and hits send.

The distance between them was never an ocean. It was a grave.

The elevator dings softly in the hallway, ready.

End of Scene 4

The heat hits first—wet asphalt baking under rotor fuel—then the smell: scorched pine sap, burnt flesh, and the metallic tang of cordite threading through cold October rain. Isa tastes all of it while she claws across the shredded cockpit, left arm dangling like a snapped cable. Her shoulder had popped on impact; every heartbeat shoves the ball of the joint farther out of its socket, but the pain is a distant radio station compared to the hiss of leaking avgas.

“Klaus.” Voice cracked, not hers—too close to the scream she swallowed when the tail rotor disintegrated. She finds the pilot slumped against the cyclic, helmet caved on the left. Blood channels down his cheek, mixing with rain that drips through the ragged hole where the windshield used to be.

She wedges her right arm under his armpit, fingers slipping on the Nomex. The chopper groans—aluminum ribs protesting like a dying animal. Better to drag them both out now than wait for the fire to decide their exit strategy. She plants her boots on the buckled instrument panel, knees trembling, and pulls.

Something tears in her shoulder—hot copper wire through muscle—but Klaus slides six inches closer to the doorframe. Another heave. The world tilts, concussion ringing church bells between her ears, but she keeps the rhythm: inhale, brace, drag. Each exhale steams in the frigid air before the rain erases it.

Fuel pools under the belly, rainbow slicks swirling over pine needles. One spark and they’ll be barbecue in dress blues. She tastes fuel on her tongue—thin, chemical—and forces herself to move faster. Another yard. Klaus’s boot snags on the doorframe; she kicks it free, then rolls them both into the underbrush.

The helicopter sighs, metal cooling fast. Smoke curls into the dripping canopy like incense gone wrong. Isa collapses chest-first onto sodden leaves, shoulder screaming, breath sawing. Rain needles her scalp, washing soot into her eyes.

She checks Klaus—pulse steady, skull fracture probable. No exit wound. Good. Then she wills herself upright.

That’s when she sees it, half-buried under a smoldering blue spruce: a jagged shard of metal no bigger than a dinner plate, edges still glowing. Cyrillic lettering stamped along the inner curve, the paint scorched but readable. Isa’s throat closes.

She knows the script from field hospitals outside Grozny, from the crates the rebels never bothered to relabel. Not some stray MANPAD from the desert. This came east—deliberate, tracked. Someone wanted them down.

Her phone buzzes against her hip. 14:37. Unknown caller. The screen shows a thumbnail: Luna blindfolded, wrists zip-tied, breathing through a plastic straw. A distorted voice loops three seconds of childhood French-Korean lullaby, then cuts to static.

Isa’s hand tightens on the shard, Cyrillic letters branding her palm. Cold rain drums on the metal like morse code.

Behind her, Klaus moans—soft, almost apologetic. She shoves the shard into her pocket, wipes blood off her lip, and starts the countdown in her head.

Five minutes to find signal. Ten to reach Ramstein med-evac. Then the river. Always the river.

She braces her good arm under Klaus’s shoulders and hauls him deeper into the forest, boots squelching, rain washing the crash site into a watercolor blur. Somewhere ahead, a logging road, a radio, a way back to the coordinates buried under decades of silence.

The lullaby keeps playing in her skull—off-tempo, vowels stretched like taffy. Isa clenches her teeth and walks faster, shoulder grinding, the Black Forest closing in like a green fist.

The orchids had been perfect—phalaenopsis in pearl white, potted in black river stones, their roots glistening like wet bone. Caro had arranged them herself at dawn, tweezing each stem into place while Min practiced his hanja at the kitchen counter, tongue poking from the corner of his mouth. Now the tray slips from her fingers as if gravity has doubled, orchids cartwheeling through the air in slow motion.

Porcelain bursts against marble with a sound like ice breaking over deep water. Potting mix sprays across the floor in dark, wet applause. A shard spins up, kisses her right palm, and keeps spinning. Blood beads, fat as pomegranate seeds, before gravity reasserts itself and they roll down her wrist in hot streaks.

The tablet lies three feet away, screen cracked but still alive. Min’s reflection flickers inside it—nine years old, cheeks round with baby fat, blindfold white as surgical gauze. The straw between his lips trembles with every breath.

“Dors, mon trésor, 자장가를 불러,” the voice drones, electronic and sexless, as if the lullaby were being sung by the air itself.

Caro’s knees hit the floor hard enough to bruise. She doesn’t feel it. Her fingers, slick with blood, crawl toward the screen. They hover over Min’s face, afraid to touch, terrified to discover he’s only two-dimensional.

The timestamp burns in the corner: 14:37. She has watched it loop four times now. Each cycle ends with the same instruction: Return to the river where you buried the truth.

River.

Her mind snags on the word like fabric on barbed wire. There is only one river that ever mattered. The Rhine, slate-gray and fast beneath the Hohenzollern Bridge, its surface chopped into silver scales by the wind. The night she and Isa stood on the pedestrian walkway, seventeen years old, sharing a cigarette they didn’t want and a secret they couldn’t carry. The night they swore never to speak of it again—not to each other, not to anyone.

Caro’s reflection blurs in the black screen. The woman staring back is flawless until the blood drips off her chin and mars the image. Somewhere below, Seoul honks and blinks, a circuit board of neon and ambition. Up here, the air smells of broken stems and spilled soil, humid, sweet, rotting.

She tries to stand. Her legs refuse. Instead she crawls forward, knees grinding into porcelain grit, and drags the tablet closer. The video restarts. Min’s small chest rises, falls. The straw whistles.

“Mom,” she whispers to the empty penthouse, because there is no one else left to hear. “I’m coming.”

The word tastes foreign—Mom—not the elegant eomma she trained Min to use, but the raw, childish desperation she thought she’d outgrown. Blood smears across the screen as she swipes, searching for metadata, GPS, anything. Nothing. Whoever took him knew how to scrub a feed clean.

Outside, the Han River glints between skyscrapers, a dull ribbon of light. Not the Rhine. Not the right river. But close enough to mock her.

Caro presses her bleeding palm to the cool marble. The pain grounds her, sharp and bright. She breathes through it, counting heartbeats. One, two, three—

She rises. Glass crunches under her Louboutins. The orchids lie in pieces, petals bruised purple at the edges like fingerprints. She steps over them, leaving bloody half-moons on the floor.

In the bedroom she yanks a duffel from the closet. Passport, cash, burner phone—she’s never unpacked the go-bag since the last time. The last time she swore she’d never run again.

The tablet is still playing when she returns. Min’s shoulders jerk; someone off-screen adjusts the straw. A freight-container echo hollows every breath. Caro pauses the video on his face, captures the still, sends it to an encrypted server in Luxembourg, then wipes the tablet clean with the tail of her silk blouse.

She slings the duffel over her shoulder. At the elevator, she hesitates, looks back. The penthouse gleams—white leather, chrome, orchid petals like fallen wings. A life curated to withstand any tremor.

The tremor has come from inside.

As the doors close, Caro catches her reflection one last time: hair still immaculate, blood drying in elegant streaks down her forearm. She looks like a woman who has already crossed a border and isn’t sure she’ll be allowed back.

The elevator descends. Seoul recedes above her, a hive of light. Somewhere over the Pacific, Isa is crawling from a fire she doesn’t yet know is connected. Somewhere in a box on a truck, Min is counting breaths.

Caro closes her eyes. The lullaby loops in her head, half French, half Korean, wholly theirs. She mouths the next line—the one the voice didn’t speak—and tastes seventeen again, river wind biting her cheeks, Isa’s hand slippery in hers as they dropped the bundle into the current and watched it sink.

The elevator dings. Lobby. She steps out, heels steady now. Outside, a black car waits, engine idling. She doesn’t remember calling it, but she climbs in anyway.

“Airport,” she says. “Lufthansa. First flight to Frankfurt.”

The driver nods, pulls into traffic. Seoul blurs into streaks of red and white. Caro opens her hand. The cut is deeper than she thought, a pale canyon across her lifeline. Blood wells, slow and deliberate.

She presses it to the window, leaving a small, perfect print. A signature. A promise.

The river is waiting.

# Chapter 2: Along the 37th Parallel

The wind off the Hunsrück whipped rain sideways, needling the skin like ground glass. Sodium lamps glazed the wet concrete in fractured gold, and the twin-engine Beechcraft glistened like it had been dipped in mercury. Under its wing, a woman in a dove-gray trench coat stood motionless, clutching a slim leather folio against her ribs as though keeping her heart from leaping out. Dr. Isadora Mendoza—half-Spaniard, half-Korean, all fury—hadn’t waited inside the terminal. She wanted to meet Caro on neutral ground, where the cameras ended and the sky began.

Headlights knifed through the curtain of rain. A black BMW emergency-braked beside the plane, tires hissing. The rear door opened and Park Caro unfolded herself—taller than memory, black hair shorn to a severe bob, army surplus jacket over a hanbok collar the color of bruised plums. She carried nothing. She had never believed in baggage.

For a second the only sound was the ticking of cooling engines and the wet slap of wind against fuselage. Then Caro’s boots crunched across the tarmac, each step measured, deliberate. Isa’s knuckles whitened on the folio.

Fifteen years, and the first word belonged to the weather.

“They said it would be sleet,” Caro said, voice flat, as though the forecast had personally betrayed her.

“I don’t remember asking for a reunion tour,” Isa replied. Rain beaded on her lashes; she refused to blink.

A silhouette ducked out of the cockpit—broad shoulders, bomber jacket, gray stubble cut sharp along the jawline. Klaus Reuter tossed a pair of chocks onto the ground like dice. “Ladies,” he called, Bavarian vowels rounding the word into something almost warm, “this bird is fueled and filed. If you intend to stand here until pneumonia sets in, kindly do it on your own medical insurance.”

Neither sister moved.

Ji-eun emerged from the shadows near the cargo hatch, neon pink raincoat blinding under the floodlights. She balanced a tablet in one hand and a bubble-tea straw between her teeth. At twenty-four she had already rerouted three world tours through monsoons and visa strikes; nothing about tonight seemed to dent her gloss. She tapped the screen, and a green holographic grid floated above it like spilled coolant.

“Coordinate packet decrypted,” she chirped. “Our ghost left us a breadcrumb—49.4875° N, 8.4669° E. That’s the Konrad Adenauer Bridge, Mannheim. Twelve-minute flight time if we skip de-ice.” She offered the tablet to Isa, then seemed to think better and angled it toward Caro instead. Diplomacy through gadget placement.

Caro glanced at the numbers, lips compressing. “Mom’s bridge,” she said. The words cracked like thawing ice.

Isa flinched almost imperceptibly. “We don’t know this is about her.”

Caro’s laugh scraped. “Of course not. Random psychopaths always scatter GPS poetry over the Rhine.”

Klaus stepped between them, palms raised. “My hangar, my rules. Grief later, altitude now. Mendoza, your medical kit’s aboard. Park, I’ve got a thermos of yuja-cha that hasn’t gone cold yet. Both of you—inside before customs wonders why a retired Bundeswehr pilot is running a midnight taxi service.”

For a heartbeat, the only thing louder than the rain was the sisters’ resistance. Then Caro moved first, brushing past Isa close enough that the wool of their coats snagged for an instant, a static spark snapping between them. Isa smelled the starched collar of her own lab coat under the trench, the ghost of antiseptic she could never quite scrub off. Caro smelled of wet camellia and gun oil.

Inside the cabin, amber LEDs glowed like embers. Ji-eun slid into the jump seat behind the cockpit, already scrolling Russian rail-cam footage. Klaus sealed the hatch, muffling the storm to a wet heartbeat against aluminum. Isa buckled herself opposite Caro at the small fold-out table; the distance between their knees was exactly the width of the folio Isa set down like a barrier.

Caro’s gaze tracked to the folio. “Still forging paperwork?”

“Still collecting evidence,” Isa countered. She flicked the clasp, revealing a single photograph inside: two girls on a ferry railing, Han River glittering behind them, one laughing, one already looking away. She snapped it shut again.

Klaus’s voice floated back from the cockpit. “Flight time eleven minutes. Seatbelts or not, we’re wheels-up in thirty.”

Ji-eun swiveled her screen toward them. A grainy CCTV still: a teal freight container stenciled with the letters МСК-4721, riding flatbed 07 on the Trans-Siberian, timestamped three hours ago. “Hana’s ghosting the cams,” Ji-eun said. “Train’s heading east, velocity steady. If we keep leapfrogging, we intercept in Vladivostok before customs clears the manifest.”

Caro’s jaw worked. “How old is your daughter?”

“Eight,” Isa whispered.

“Mine’s ten.” Caro stared at the aisle floor as if she could bore straight through to the rails beneath. “They’re scared and moving toward the edge of the world. We don’t have time for your righteous silence.”

Isa’s reply was cut short by the engines winding up, a low moan that climbed into a howl. The plane lurched forward, rain streaking sideways across the windows like silver scars. As they rolled onto the runway, cabin lights dimmed to tactical red. On the table between them, Ji-eun set a small waterproof capsule no bigger than a shotgun shell—the kind divers use for car keys. She nudged it across until it touched both of their hands.

“Found this taped to the underside of the flap actuator,” she said. “It wasn’t there at pre-flight.”

Through the translucent casing glinted a flash drive and a folded slip of hanja inked in blood-red brushstrokes. Caro’s breath hitched; Isa felt it in her own lungs, a twin catch.

The Beechcraft lifted, the ground falling away into black mosaic. Somewhere below, the Rhine coiled like a steel ribbon. Ahead, the 37th Parallel waited, a scar across continents and memory.

Caro unfolded the slip with trembling fingers. The lullaby—first line in their mother’s hand. Isa read over her shoulder, translating in a whisper neither of them had meant to share:

“Little boats set sail before dawn…”

They looked at each other, rain still dripping from their hair, engines hammering toward Mannheim, and for a moment the resentment was eclipsed by something colder: recognition.

The hangar doors groaned shut behind them, sealing out the rain and the whine of departing cargo jets. Sodium lamps buzzed overhead, washing the corrugated metal walls in bruise-colored light. A single Cessna 340 sat on the oil-stained concrete like a patient predator, its props still dripping. Between the plane’s nose and a stack of palletized freight, two trestle tables had been pushed together to make an impromptu war room.

Klaus smoothed the map with the heel of his hand. The paper crackled, loud in the hush of the hangar. A red grease-pencil line ran east-west across Europe, kissing coastlines and mountain ranges before diving into Asia. Tiny black triangles marched along it—waypoints, numbered but unnamed.

“Thirty-seven degrees north,” Klaus said, tapping the line. “Your mother used to call it the seam between worlds. Tonight we follow it east, one checkpoint at a time, until the kidnapper tells us to stop.”

Caro leaned in. Rainwater slid from the brim of her cap onto the map, beading on the laminated surface. “Checkpoint one is Mannheim?” Her voice was hoarse from the cold, but steady.

“Rhine kilometer three-sixty-nine,” Ji-eun confirmed. She wore the same leather bomber she’d had since Kosovo, patches faded to gray. In her gloved fingers she held a brushed-steel capsule no larger than a .50-caliber round. “We lifted this off the drone that overflew Hahn an hour ago. Waterproof, pressure-proof. Whoever sent it knew we’d be here.”

Isa stood a pace behind her sister, arms folded so tight her knuckles blanched. The borrowed parka smelled of jet fuel and someone else’s cigarettes. “Mannheim,” she repeated, tasting iron. “You mean the bridge where we—”

“Where we dumped Mom’s ashes, yes.” Caro’s chin lifted. “Don’t say dumped, Isa. She asked us to scatter them there. You were too busy catching your flight to Seoul to remember the exact wording.”

The words hit like buckshot. Isa felt the sting travel all the way to her wrists. “I had orders,” she said. “Medical rotation at Yongsan. I told you a hundred times—”

“While my brother was bleeding out near Cheorwon,” Caro snapped. “But sure, save the ones who can pay.”

Klaus cleared his throat. “Ladies, we have maybe six hours before the container crosses the Ukrainian border. If you’re going to knife each other, do it after we’re airborne.”

Isa stepped to the table, forcing herself to look at the map instead of Caro’s face. The grease-pencil line passed through places she’d only seen from a helicopter gunship: the Black Sea, the Caucasus, the empty quarter north of Vladivostok. At the edge of the paper someone had written a string of coordinates in Ji-eun’s tidy engineer’s script—49.4875° N, 8.4669° E. Mannheim. A small black star marked the spot.

Ji-eun unscrewed the capsule. Inside lay a thumb drive and a slip of rice paper folded into a square. She tweezed the paper out with forceps and laid it flat. Hanja characters glimmered like fish scales under the lamps.

Caro’s breath caught. “That’s Mom’s handwriting.”

Ji-eun angled the paper toward them. “I can’t read it,” she admitted. “But the drive’s labeled with the same characters.”

Isa’s throat closed. She recognized the first character—moon—followed by one she’d never bothered to learn. A childhood memory surfaced: their mother humming against her ear, tracing the shapes on her palm so Isa could fall asleep on the Seoul subway. She’d called hanja “self-indulgent grief” once, loud enough for Caro to hear. The fight that followed had lasted a week.

Caro reached for the paper, then stopped, fingers hovering. “Read it,” she said to Isa, voice low. “You always insisted you forgot.”

“I didn’t forget,” Isa muttered. “I just—” She swallowed. “I didn’t want to remember.”

Silence stretched until the lamps seemed to buzz louder. Klaus shifted his weight, boots scuffing concrete.

Ji-eun broke it. She spoke the line aloud, syllable by syllable, her pronunciation clipped but careful. “Dal-bit… mul-eul… geu-ri-go…” Moonlight on the water, longing for… something. Isa couldn’t parse the last measure. The rice paper trembled between Ji-eun’s forceps like a living thing.

Caro’s eyes glistened, but her tone was flat. “She used to sing that when you had night terrors. After Dad died. You’d wake up screaming and she’d rock you, singing about moonlight and the river, telling you the dead could still hear us if we spoke their names.”

Isa felt the hangar tilt. The concrete seemed to ripple under her boots. “I was eight,” she said. “I didn’t know what any of it meant.”

“But you knew enough to erase it.” Caro’s voice cracked. “Just like you erased Korea, erased us.”

Ji-eun slid the drive into a hardened tablet. The screen woke, casting blue light across their faces. A 1996 Red Cross crest appeared, pixelated but unmistakable. Below it: OPERATION WHITE PINE – RESTRICTED. She angled the tablet so both sisters could see.

“Whatever’s on this,” Ji-eun said, “it ties your mother to a massacre. And the kidnapper wants you to watch it together. Now.”

Caro wiped her eyes with the heel of her hand, smearing mascara across her cheek. “Fine. We watch. Then we go to Mannheim. But understand this, Isa: every step we take, you carry the weight of what you walked away from.”

Isa met her gaze, something hard crystallizing behind her own exhaustion. “I carried plenty, Caro. Just because I didn’t bleed in the same mud doesn’t mean I didn’t bleed.”

Klaus folded the map with military precision, creases sharp enough to cut. “Bleed on your own time,” he said. “Weather window closes in forty minutes. You can kill each other after we’re wheels-up, but right now we move.”

He snapped off the overhead lamps, plunging them into the dim glow of emergency strips. The Cessna’s door yawned open like a mouth. Isa grabbed her duffel, the weight of the drive and the rice paper suddenly heavier than body armor.

Caro was already climbing the airstair. She paused halfway, looking back. “Moonlight on the water,” she said. “Keep humming it, Isa. Maybe the dead will forgive you.”

Isa followed, rain misting through the open door onto her face, tasting of runway salt and something else—ashes, maybe, or memory. She didn’t answer, but the tune was already threading itself behind her teeth, soft as breath, relentless as the 37th parallel itself.

The props began to turn.

The wind comes off the Rhine like a slap, slicing through Isa’s coat and carrying the smell of diesel and wet stone. She grips the railing, knuckles whitening. Below, the river slides black and wide beneath the iron lattice of the bridge, its surface freckled by rain.

Caro stands ten feet away at the opposite parapet, one boot hooked on the lowest rung of the maintenance ladder that snakes down into the girders. She doesn’t look back when she speaks. “49.4875 North, 8.4669 East. This is it. Exact middle of the span.”

Isa’s mouth tastes of metal. She hasn’t stood here since the day they opened their mother’s urn and the ashes scattered like pale wings—fine enough to ride the updraft, coarse enough that some grains stuck to her wet lashes. That was fifteen years ago, the same autumn chill, the same river hush. Same guilt.

Caro descends two rungs. Ice crackles under her gloves. “You coming or just cataloging regrets?”

Isa swallows. “I’m coming.”

The lattice is a skeleton of rust-red beams and cross-braces, slick with November rain. They climb sideways, backs to the water, boots wedging for purchase. Isa’s breath fogs the rivets. Each step knocks loose a memory: the soft weight of the urn in her arms, Caro’s voice cracking on the Korean prayer she never bothered to learn, the plink of bone fragments against the railing.

Halfway down, Caro stops. “There.”

A finger-thick capsule, matte orange, clipped to a cable with a stainless-steel carabiner. It sways in the wind, tapping the iron like a heartbeat. Caro reaches first, fingers brushing it, then hesitates. “You do it.”

Isa blinks rain from her lashes. “Why?”

“Because you owe her more than I do.”

The words sting sharper than the wind. Isa unhooks the capsule. It’s heavier than expected, the plastic scored by cold. She thumbs the rubber gasket, feels the O-ring give. Inside: a thumb drive sealed in a tiny zip-bag and a folded square of rice paper.

Caro climbs back up to the walkway. Isa follows, boots slipping once, the river yawning below. On the pavement they huddle under the weak orange glow of a sodium lamp. Rain drums the awning of a locked souvenir kiosk.

Caro tears open the zip-bag with her teeth. The drive is unmarked, gunmetal gray. Isa unfolds the rice paper. Hanja characters bloom like bruises across the grain:

잠이 들면 / 바람결에 / 그림자 피고
When you sleep / in the path of the wind / shadows take root

Her throat locks. She hears the lullaby in their mother’s voice, the low hum she used when Seoul’s sirens went off and the blackout curtains couldn’t muffle the world. Isa had pretended not to know the words; easier to fake sleep than admit she understood every syllable and still enlisted under a forged medical waiver.

Caro’s voice is almost drowned by the rain. “She wrote that the week before she left for Bosnia.” A pause. “You never asked what it meant.”

“I was nineteen,” Isa mutters. “I thought meaning was negotiable.”

Caro wipes water from her brow with the heel of her hand. “Let’s see what else she left us.”

She pulls a rugged tablet from her coat, slots the drive. A folder opens: RC_96-11-17_Medak_Pocket_Redacted.pdf. The thumbnail shows a Red Cross crest, a stamp reading SECRET—EYES ONLY. Caro taps it. Lines of blacked-out Cyrillic and English scroll past. A photograph unblurs: a woman in blue coveralls, face obscured by a surgical mask, but the eyes—dark, certain—belong unmistakably to their mother.

Isa’s pulse skids. “She was there. November ’96. Medak Pocket.”

Caro’s reply is a whisper. “And she never told us.”

Below them a barge horn moans, low and mournful. Headlights sweep the bridge as a lone car crosses, tires hissing on wet asphalt. Isa folds the rice paper back into its square, creasing the edges like a prayer.

Caro pockets the drive. “Next coordinate?”

Isa checks the phone: 48.3026 N 14.2861 E. Danube, Linz. She angles the screen so Caro can see the blue pin hovering over Austria.

Caro exhales a cloud of frost. “More ghosts, then.”

Isa almost smiles. “We’re good at ghosts.”

They start back toward the rental car, footfalls syncing without meaning to. Behind them the bridge hums, the capsule’s empty carabiner still swinging like a pendulum marking time neither of them can get back.

The Mercedes Sprinter shuddered over a pothole, sending coffee sloshing against the travel-cup lid. Outside, the A6 sliced through vineyards glazed silver by the floodlights of passing trucks. Inside, the air felt thinner, like someone had cracked a window to November and left the grief inside to sour.

Ji-eun sat sideways on the wheel-well, laptop balanced on her knees, the flash drive pinched between latex-gloved fingers. Klaus drove one-handed, the other resting on a matte-black thigh holster he hadn’t bothered to hide since Mannheim. In the back, Caro and Isa knelt on opposite sides of a mil-spec crate, its lid open to reveal a folded tarp, nylon cuffs, and—now—the slim silver drive spinning mercilessly in the USB hub.

Isa’s breath fogged the cold glass of the sliding door. She watched the Neckar’s black ribbon appear and vanish between stands of frost-bitten poplars. Each mile felt like a seam ripping open inside her chest.

Ji-eun tapped a key. The screen blinked from encrypted static to pale institutional gray. A Red Cross emblem, 1996 vintage, jittered into focus.

“Fragment found,” Ji-eun said, voice almost apologetic. “Audio only. Ninety-three seconds.”

The van speakers crackled, then a woman’s calm European French:
“—the compound at Sajik-dong, 3 July 1950. Approximately 2100 hours. Mothers instructed to sing to prevent the children from crying—”

A lullaby started underneath, soft, unmistakably Korean: the same melody their mother had hummed when fever kept Isa awake, the same Caro later mocked as “cheap sedation.” On the tape it warbled, overexposed, like wind through cracked church glass.

“—before the soldiers opened fire. Only two girls survived, hidden beneath the bodies. One was listed as Kim Eun-hee, age seven. The other’s name is redacted in this copy.”

The recording cut to static. Isa felt the sound in her teeth.

Caro’s fist closed around the tarp edge until the fabric bunched like pleated skin. “She never told us.”

“She told us plenty,” Isa said, too quickly.

“She told bedtime stories. Not mass graves.” Caro’s voice scraped raw. She reached toward the keyboard; Ji-eun angled the screen away, protective. “You never wanted the real stories. You called han ‘self-indulgent grief,’ remember? Signed your medical exemption, flew to Berlin, and left the rest of us to carry it.”

The accusation hung over the drone of tires.

Isa swallowed. The coffee tasted like rust. “They would’ve sent me to the DMZ to stitch up kids who stepped on mines. I couldn’t do it. I chose life—”

“You chose absence,” Caro snapped. “While my brother—” She broke off, pressing knuckles to her mouth. The name didn’t need saying; it lived between them like a third sibling who refused to leave the room.

Klaus’s eyes flicked to the rearview mirror, gauging threat levels. Ji-eun paused the playback, leaving the screen frozen on the Red Cross timestamp: 03-07-1950. The date glowed green, accusing.

Isa’s phone buzzed on the crate—unknown number, voice-scramble icon already spinning. She put it on speaker before thinking.

A wash of digital gravel filled the van. Luna.

“Did you like your mother’s lullaby in surround sound?” The voice modulated up, childlike, then plunged baritone. “Next verse awaits. Coordinates: 49.4875° N, 8.4669° E—”

“That’s where we just came from,” Klaus growled.

“Recalculating,” Luna cooed. “Apologies. New drop: 48.7758° N, 9.1829° E. Stuttgart-Münster. Midnight. Bring your passports; borders are thinning.”

The line clicked dead. Silence stretched, elastic and sour.

Caro’s reflection stared at Isa from the dark window: twin pairs of exhausted eyes, fifteen years of distance compressed into one vibrating moment. She spoke first, softer now. “That redacted name. It’s her, isn’t it? Our mother.”

Isa’s throat closed. She managed a nod.

Outside, a road sign flashed: STUTTGART 47 km. The van’s speed crept up, tires humming a low lullaby of their own.

Ji-eun quietly closed the laptop. Klaus flicked on the high beams, cutting tunnels through the night. In the sudden cone of light, the next stretch of autobahn looked like an unhealed scar, and they were all just passengers on its back, heading east, always east, chasing the fragments of a song no one wanted to finish.

The civic’s headlights cut a dim tunnel through the fog rolling off the Neckar, silver needles of rain stabbing the windshield. Isa killed the engine beside a picnic pull-off whose tables squatted like darkened sarcophagi. Beyond the guardrail the river ran black and fast, its surface flicking light back at the sodium lamps. Klaus stepped out first, coat collar high, cigarette cupped in one hand. Ji-eun lingered near the hood, tablet glowing against the night.

Inside the car the dashboard clock read 02:17. Caro’s phone buzzed on the center console, speaker crackling.

“Mom, I’m in,” Hana said, voice thin with adrenaline. “Russian Railways subnet thought six-factor was enough—cute.” Rapid keystrokes sounded like hail on metal. “Okay, camera 14B just pinged the freight train at Omsk, timestamp twenty-three minutes ago. Same container ID: BGX-777-KR. Eastbound on the Trans-Sib mainline.”

Isa leaned forward, damp hair brushing Caro’s shoulder. “ETA to Vladivostok?”

“At current speed—three days, ten hours, assuming no sidings or bribes. Satellite weather shows a storm front over the Urals; could add half a day.”

Caro rubbed her temples. “We’ll be neck-deep in Bavarian snow by then. Keep the feed open.”

“It’s chewing bandwidth,” Hana warned. “I’ve got a relay piggybacking a Roscosmos weather sat, but it’ll decay in four hours.”

“Four hours is luxury,” Klaus muttered through the open window. Smoke ghosted around his words.

Ji-eun tapped the tablet. “Next coordinate from the capsule: 49.4875° N, 8.4669° E—that’s still Mannheim, but the Rhine crossing is behind us. The Neckar waypoint must be verification, not destination.”

“Or a breadcrumb,” Isa said. “Luna likes loops.”

Caro opened the glove box and drew out the silver capsule they’d pried from the bridge lattice hours earlier. The flash drive dangled like a tiny sword. She stared at the Korean hanja etched inside the cap: 잠이 들어도 꿈은 날아간다—Even in sleep, dreams take flight.

A sudden hush fell, broken only by the river and the soft rustle of rain. Isa watched Caro trace the characters with a fingertip, the gesture hesitant, almost tender.

“You used to hum that line,” Caro said quietly, eyes still on the metal. “At the hospital, after Dad left the second time. You were twelve, maybe thirteen. I hated you for sounding like Mom.”

Isa’s throat worked. “I didn’t know you were listening.”

“I hid on the landing.” Caro’s laugh was small, cracked. “You sat on the piano bench in your school uniform, rocking like she used to. I thought if I came down, you’d stop, and I didn’t want the song to end.”

Rain drummed on the roof. Isa reached into her jacket and produced the folded page—Hana’s transcription of the lullaby fragments. She smoothed it against the steering wheel. “We have two stanzas now. If the next line is at the Neckar, maybe the river keeps the rest.”

“Rivers don’t keep,” Caro said. “They carry away.”

Isa flinched but didn’t retreat. “Then let’s move before the current wins.”

Headlights flared behind them—Klaus, ready to roll. Ji-eun climbed into the back seat, tablet balanced on her knees like a prayer book. Caro twisted the key; the engine coughed awake. She eased onto the wet road, tires hissing. In the rearview the picnic tables receded, then vanished as fog swallowed them.

“Hana,” Caro said, “patch the feed to the windshield HUD once we hit the autobahn. If the container stalls, I want to see it before the Russians do.”

“Copy. And Mom… the lullaby.” A pause, soft as breath. “Grandma used to sing it to me over video chat. Same key you hum. Thought you should know.”

Caro’s grip tightened on the wheel. The car crested the rise; ahead, the highway signs gleamed green and white. BADEN-WÜRTTEMBERG 42 KM.
